p: Acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs) are the most common cause of childhood morbidity and mortality worldwide, accounting for about 30% of all childhood deaths in the developing world [ 1]. The WHO estimates that ARTIs account for 1.9 to 2.2 million childhood deaths annually, with 42% occurring in Africa [ 2]. The etiologic agents include viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Among the viruses responsible for ARTIs are members of the Orthomyxoviridae, Coronaviridae, Picornaviridae, Paramyxoviridae, Adenoviridae, and Parvoviridae. Bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae ( S. pneumoniae), Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus, Moraxella catarrhalis, Mycoplasma pneumoniae ( M. pneumoniae), and Chlamydia pneumoniae are the most common involved microbes [ 3]. However, in general, viral infections are shown to be responsible for about 80% of ARTIs and are the cause of 90% of hospitalizations in children below 5 years of age [ 4].
